content.full_text: Secondary diabetes may be caused by an adverse effect of correctly administered medications, poisoning or sequela of poisoning. See section I.C.19.e. for coding of adverse effects and poisoning, and section I.C.20 for external cause code reporting. (Evidence: pg no: 42, L12-L15)
content.summary: Explains that drug-induced secondary diabetes can result from adverse effects, poisoning, or sequelae, with references to specific coding sections for proper coding (Evidence: pg no: 42, L12-L15)
key_concepts: Drug-induced secondary diabetes causes (Evidence: pg no: 42, L12-L14)
Adverse effects vs poisoning distinction (Evidence: pg no: 42, L13-L14)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Secondary diabetes may result from adverse effects of correctly administered medications (Evidence: pg no: 42, L12-L13)
detailed_rules.explanation: When medications are given correctly but cause diabetes as an unintended consequence, this is classified as an adverse effect (Evidence: pg no: 42, L12-L13)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Secondary diabetes may result from poisoning or sequela of poisoning (Evidence: pg no: 42, L13-L14)
detailed_rules.explanation: When diabetes results from drug overdose, wrong drug, or long-term effects of previous poisoning (Evidence: pg no: 42, L13-L14)

workflow_steps: Step 2: Determine if adverse effect, poisoning, or sequela
